questions.question_text:
A security analyst is implementing PKI-based functionality to a web application that has the following requirements:
✑ File contains certificate information
✑ Certificate chains
✑ Root authority certificates
✑ Private key
All of these components will be part of one file and cryptographically protected with a password. Given this scenario, which of the following certificate types should the analyst implement to BEST meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
A.
Search Results
Featured snippet from the web
A PFX file, also known as PKCS #12 , is a single, password protected certificate archive that contains the entire certificate chain plus the matching private key. Essentially it is everything that any server will need to import a certificate and private key from a single file.

DER >>> Stores single certificates, certificate chains, or private keys. Uses either a .der or .cer extension.
PEM >>> It may contain single certificates, certificate chains, or private keys. Comes in a number of different file extensions: .pem, .crt, .cer, and .key.
PFX/PKCS#12 >>> It may contain single certificates, certificate chains, or private keys, although in most cases it is used to store public/private key pairs. Fully encrypt all the data in the file and require a password to open them. Uses the extension .pfx or .p12.
(Mike Meyers’ CompTIA Security+ p. 465-466)

P12, PFX: commonly used to store private key
P7B: used to store public key
PEM: can be used for almost any certificate purpose
DER: used for binary certificate
CER: used for ASCII certificates
A. PFX certificates are commonly used to hold the private key.

questions.question_text: Which of the following encryption algorithms is used primarily to secure data at rest?

discussion.content: Encryption at rest aims to secure data at rest, often using the Advanced Encryption standard (AES).

questions.question_text: A security auditor is performing a vulnerability scan to find out if mobile applications used in the organization are secure. The auditor discovers that one application has been accessed remotely with no legitimate account credentials. After investigating, it seems the application has allowed some users to bypass authentication of that application. Which of the following types of malware allow such a compromise to take place? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: a backdoor provides another way to access a system. Many types of malware create backdoors, allowing attackers to access systems from remote locations. employees also created backdoors in applications and systems.

remotely: RAT
 some users : Backdoor
The given answers are correct. Remote Access Trojan is considered as a backdoor as well. So, yeah A&E are correct answers.
I dont think its trojan, so I might choose A, E
Backdoor is not a malware! it is part of the payload of a malware but not a malware, so it should be RAT and something else. I think Trojan or Worm

comments.content: I think if a backdoor was made and implemented without the company’s/developer’s/user’s knowledge and consent, it is to be considered malware, especially when it is being used for malicious purposes.

A backdoor is a malware type that negates normal authentication procedures to access a system.
https://www.imperva.com/learn/application-security/backdoor-shell-attack/#:~:text=A%20backdoor%20is%20a%20malware,system%20commands%20and%20update%20malware.

discussion.content:
A D E Is it a Backdoor, Root Kit, a Trojan, or a RAT... It doesn't really matter... They're all the same thing. (The term “RAT” (Remote Access Trojan) can be considered a synonym to “backdoor” (RAT = Remote Acccess Trojan / Remote Access Tool / Remote Admin Tool. A trojan deals with the same concept (client/server) but is usually used for malicious purposes and isn't usually authorized by the victim. It is typically used to control another PC from afar . 
http://www.antionline.com/showthread.php?270865-RATS-Vs-TROJANS/page2

discussion.content: This was on my exam (5 Aug 2020). Obviously when you see "Faraday cage" among the answers, go for it; 9 out of 10 it's the winner. It's a kind of universal remedy to all cybersecurity issues. At least according to these CompTIA geniuses.
Faraday cage wins the day

Its very unlikely someone to be able to install faraday cage once the building is operational, instead A seems much more convenient in this case. But as other said, faraday cage everywhere. . I thought to get one too ... just like that.

Comptia should by this domain "Faradaycages.com" . They love it!!!!
Wow, so they vote to encase an entire building in metal mesh rather than just upgrading cables? Ok then. I thought that was a joke of an answer. Go big or go home I guess.

again, faraday cages! 
How many times did we see this as answer on this 501 test
nuaaaaa
Making a large building into a Faraday cage involves encasing the building in a thin layer of conductive material or metal mesh.

choices.A: Upgrading facility cabling to a higher standard of protected cabling to reduce the likelihood of emission spillage
choices.D: Employing security guards to ensure unauthorized personnel remain outside of the facility
choices.B: Hardening the facility through the use of secure cabinetry to block emissions
choices.C: Hardening the facility with a Faraday cage to contain emissions produced from data processing

questions.question_text: An organization electronically processes sensitive data within a controlled facility. The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) wants to limit emissions from emanating from the facility. Which of the following mitigates this risk?

As part of a corporate merger, two companies are combining resources. As a result, they must transfer files through the Internet in a secure manner. Which of the following protocols would BEST meet this objective? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: Although the security models are very different – SSL/TLS for HTTPS, and SSH for SFTP – they are both very secure protocols. ... HTTPS may have a small advantage over SFTP, but this will depend on client implementations.
Answers: B and C
@abady, it says through the internet so a secured protocol is required. HTTPS 443
first Q straightforward
Shouldn't this be B and E? What does HTTPS have to do with transferring files?

comments.content: SRTP(Secure Real Time Protocol) - used for secure voice and video connections. So it's not relevant here

You absolutely can use HTTPS to download files, although SFTP would be preferred. We've all downloaded files from a browser - like downloading a Linux distro from a web server. SRTP makes real time transport protocol secure - but this isn't downloading a file - it is transporting a voice data stream.
